awd_titl_txt: The 5th North American Spring School on Medical Robotics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is to support travel by up to 50 student participants to attend the 2019 Spring School on Medical Robotics.  All of the supported students are attending US institutions.

This grant is a conference support grant for the expenses of up to 50 selected U.S. trainees (PhD students and post-doctoral fellows of various disciplinary backgrounds pertaining to medical/surgical robotics, image-guided interventions, surgical simulation and training, biomechatronics, rehabilitation robotics, and medical devices) attending the 5th North American School on Medical Robotics - "2019 Spring School on Medical Robotics". The School will be held at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, Georgia, from April 1-2, 2019 to introduce and educate trainees on the ground- breaking research and opportunities in surgical robotics, image-guided medical interventions, surgical simulation and training, rehabilitation robotics, etc. Organized in part by the Georgia Institute of Technology, the school focuses on providing a forum to exchange scientific findings, discuss recent research progress, identify areas requiring greater emphasis, set research goals for collaborations, recognize outstanding achievement in the field, and promote the study of medical robotics to young scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

por.por_cntn:
Major Activities:

This Spring School on Medical Robotics was the 5th North American School on Medical Robotics. There were over 50 participants including clinicians, academics, researchers, and engineers. We had 16 experts from around the world to give lectures on the topic of medical robotics.

Specific Objectives:

To introduce and educate trainees on the ground-breaking research and opportunities in surgical robotics, image-guided medical interventions, surgical simulation and training and rehabilitation robotics. 

Significant Results:

16 educational lectures in the areas of medical/surgical robotics, image-guided interventions, surgical simulation and training, biomechatronics, rehabilitation robotics, and medical devices were delivered including the below speakers who are all well established in the field.

  • Aaron Young, Georgia Institute of Technology, USA
  • Antoine Ferreira, INSA Centre Val de Loire, France
  • Arianna Menciassi, Scuola Superiore Sant'Anna, Italy
  • Cameron Riviere, Carnegie Mellon University, USA
  • Elena De Momi, Politecnico di Milano, Italy
  • Gabor Fichtinger, Queen’s University, Canada
  • Jun Ueda, Georgia Institute of Technology, USA
  • Mahdi Tavakoli, University of Alberta, Canada
  • Nabil Simaan, Vanderbilt University, USA
  • Paolo Fiorini, University of Verona, Italy  
  • Philippe Poignet, LIRMM, CNRS - Université de Montpellier, France
  • Pretesh R. Patel, Emory University, USA
  • Russell H. Taylor, The Johns Hopkins University, USA
  • Sai Muralidhar Padala, Emory University, USA
  • Simon DiMaio, Intuitive Surgical, Inc., USA
  • Zion Tse, University of Georgia, USA

Key outcomes or Other achievements:

The School provided a forum to exchange scientific findings, discuss recent research progress, identify areas requiring greater emphasis, set research goals for collaborations, recognize outstanding achievements in the field, and promote the study of medical robotics to young scientists.

 


Last Modified: 07/19/2021
Modified by: Tsz Ho Tse
